description.narrative:
Raoul Wallenberg Institute (RWI) has applied to Sida for funding of 14,5 million SEK to carry out the "RWI Turkey Human Rights Capacity Development Programme 19-20" during the period 2019-2010.
The intervention aims to strengthen human rights education at targeted institutions, to strengthen networking and gender-integrated research capacity among human rights researchers and to promote solution-oriented dialogue between policy-makers, academia, civil society organisations to advance human rights, gender equality and access to justice from an inclusion perspective.
The intervention’s total budget is 14,5 million SEK.

Raoul Wallenberg Institutet (RWI) har ansökt till Sida om finansiering på 14,5 miljoner SEK för att genomföra "RWI Turkiet Mänskliga Rättigheter Kapacitetsutveckling Program 19-20" under perioden 2019-2020.
Insatsens mål är att stärka utbildning hos turkiska universitet för att bedriva forskning inom mänskliga rättigheter och jämställdhet samt att främja nätverkande inom områdena mellan aktörer och att stötta en lösningsorienterad dialog mellan beslutsfattare, akademi, civilsamhälleorganisationer och ökad tillgång till rättvisa från ett inkluderande perspektiv.
Insatsens totala finansiering är 14,5 miljoner SEK.

Target Area 1Main objective: To strengthen human rights education at targeted institutions.Outcome: Human rights education of high quality increasingly provided at targeted institutions in a manner promoting gender equality Target Area 2Main objective: To strengthen networking and gender-integrated research capacity among human rights researchersOutcome: Increased availability and accessibility of high quality gender-integrated human rights research and related policy recommendations of key relevance to the Turkish context Target Area 3Main objective: To promote solution-oriented dialogue between policy-makers, academia, civil society organisations to advance human rights, gender equality and access to justice from an inclusion perspective.Outcome: Strengthened interaction between academic institutions, municipalities, state actors, private sector actors and civil society organisations improving human rights work to meet rights-holders’ claims from an inclusion and gender perspective

tag.narrative: 11.7 - By 2030, provide universal access to safe, inclusive and accessible, green and public spaces, in particular for women and children, older persons and persons with disabilities.

11.7 - Senast 2030 tillhandahålla universell tillgång till säkra, inkluderande och tillgängliga grönområden och offentliga platser, i synnerhet för kvinnor och barn, äldre personer och personer med funktionsnedsättning.
16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
17.17 - Encourage and promote effective public, public-private and civil society partnerships, building on the experience and resourcing strategies of partnerships
17.17 - Encourage and promote effective public, public-private and civil society partnerships, building on the experience and resourcing strategies of partnerships.
5.c - Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.
5.c - Anta och stärka välgrundad politik och genomförbar lagstiftning för att främja jämställdhet och öka alla kvinnors och flickors egenmakt på alla nivåer

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Summarized examples of results are being based upon the narrative report covering July to December 2019. Under the first target area, RWI has continued to foster human rights and gender equality through education, training and partnerships. It consists of more specifically institutional support for mainstreaming human rights and gender quality into different disciplines (course material, syllabus). RWI has also developed something they label as Clinical Legal Education which is a problem-based teaching methodology. Through the second target area, RWI supports individual scholars (senior and junior ones) through scholarships and grants to conduct research in neglected areas such as dissability and elderly studies. RWI has been working on ensuring the link to the third target area which is to foster human rights work on local level in collaboration with civil society, academia and municipalities. RWI has supported seven municipalities to develop strategic plans based on the concept of human rights cities and to establish sub-branches within respective administration. This is a just a few examples of results achieved/activities implemented.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
